data.title: Copernicus' Heliocentric Theory
data.description: Nicolaus Copernicus publishes his heliocentric theory, proposing that the Earth revolves around the Sun.

data.title: United States Declaration of Independence
data.description: The United States Declaration of Independence is adopted, marking the birth of the United States of America.

data.title: Apollo 11 Moon Landing
data.description: Apollo 11 successfully lands the first humans, Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin, on the Moon.

data.title: Christopher Columbus' Voyage
data.description: Christopher Columbus sets sail from Spain on his first voyage across the Atlantic, reaching the Americas.

data.title: First Performance of Macbeth
data.description: William Shakespeare's play 'Macbeth' is performed for the first time in London.

data.title: End of World War II in Europe
data.description: World War II ends in Europe with the unconditional surrender of Nazi Germany.

data.title: Publication of Newton's Principia
data.description: Isaac Newton publishes 'Philosophiæ Naturalis Principia Mathematica,' introducing the laws of motion and universal gravitation.

data.title: Start of the French Revolution
data.description: The French Revolution begins with the storming of the Bastille, marking the end of the absolute monarchy in France.

data.title: Invention of the Telephone
data.description: Alexander Graham Bell patents the telephone, revolutionizing communication.

data.title: Magellan travels around the globe
data.description: Ferdinand Magellan's expedition sets off to circumnavigate the globe, ultimately proving the Earth is round.

data.title: Woodstock Festival
data.description: The Woodstock Festival, a pivotal moment in music history, takes place in upstate New York.

data.title: End of World War I
data.description: World War I ends with the signing of the Armistice of 11 November, leading to peace negotiations.

data.title: Gustav Vasa Elected King of Sweden
data.description: Gustav Vasa is elected King of Sweden, marking the end of the Kalmar Union and the beginning of modern Sweden.

data.title: Foundation of Gothenburg
data.description: Foundation of Gothenburg, a significant Swedish port city, aimed at expanding trade and maritime activities.

data.title: Publication of 'Systema Naturae'
data.description: Carl Linnaeus publishes 'Systema Naturae,' establishing the system of binomial nomenclature for species classification.

data.title: Treaty of Fredrikshamn
data.description: The Finnish War concludes with the signing of the Treaty of Fredrikshamn, resulting in the loss of Finland to Russia.

data.title: Invention of Dynamite
data.description: Alfred Nobel invents dynamite, revolutionizing the field of explosives and laying the foundation for the Nobel Prizes.

data.title: Selma Lagerlöf Wins Nobel Prize in Literature
data.description: Selma Lagerlöf becomes the first female writer to win the Nobel Prize in Literature for her work 'Gösta Berling's Saga.'

data.title: Switch to Right-Hand Traffic in Sweden
data.description: Sweden officially switches from driving on the left-hand side of the road to the right-hand side, known as Dagen H (H Day).

data.title: Invention of the World Wide Web
data.description: Tim Berners-Lee, a British computer scientist, proposes the concept of the World Wide Web, laying the groundwork for its development, which later becomes integral worldwide.

data.title: Sweden Joins the European Union
data.description: Sweden joins the European Union (EU) after a referendum in which the majority of voters supported membership.

data.title: Development of Skype
data.description: Skype, a communication platform founded by Niklas Zennström and Janus Friis, which plays a significant role in global communications, is developed in Sweden.

data.title: Bob Dylan Wins Nobel Prize in Literature
data.description: Bob Dylan, an American musician and songwriter, wins the Nobel Prize in Literature, becoming the first musician to receive this prestigious award.
